column4: Hi! I need to set up a remote root login using a public key someone sent me. How is this possible?
are you using ssh?
yes
do you have physical access to the server?  Can you go to the server and put your public key in it???
I have sudo access remotely
Is this not sufficient?
that is fine, so you want to setup your ssh key so you dont have to provide a password??
The challenge (for me) is that this needs to be for root access
if you want to login with the user "root" i highly discourage you from doing so but I can show you how to configure the SSH key
Thanks, actually the sys-admin (above me) requested this. Do you have alternative suggestions?
The instructions I got was to put the public key in /root/.ssh/authorized_keys
and you cant login???
No
Actually, the sys-admin cannot either
what error are you getting???  try ssh -v username@server

To be clear---I am trying to log in as root with my password, which is not working (I think this is expected). The sys-admin is trying with the public key, but cannot for some reason. Do you know how to generate such a key? I don't know what error he is getting
i would need to know what errors you get when you attempt to log in
sure, do you know by any chance how I can generate a public-private key pair such that one will go in authorized_keys  ? Usually, my public keys are binaries
what type of encryption are you using?  are you using rsa???
dss/dsa
you have it right, you know how to configure the keys, the question is why youre unable to login??  You can tell what is goign on by attempting to log in using verbose mode
Many thanks for your help. This gave me direction on how to resolve the problem.
in between you might want to use rsa encryption, I use rsa encryption but I'm too lazy to use a passphrase though
